items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar is falling in Alverstone and Sandown. Today (Tuesday 10/08/21) some ponded water may continue to impact low lying land and roads adjacent to the river. Over the next 5 days, apart from the odd isolated shower, the weather should be fairly dry. Further flooding is not expected, and any residual flood impacts should cease over the next 24 hours.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We are clearing debris from weed screens
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

The River Uck has now returned to near normal along its length, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Residual flood impacts might remain in fields and on rural roads. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days. The ground is now a lot wetter than normal for the time of year. Any future rainfall events in the coming weeks are likely to generate a response from the river. We will continue to monitor the river levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding could return.

River levels through Buxted have peaked and are falling, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Residual flood impacts might remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads, but with only isolated showers forecast Monday (09/08/21) and Tuesday(10/08/21), the River Uck should continue to fall overnight, and a normal water level should have returned by Tuesday morning. As a precaution, please keep flood resilience measures in place Monday and Tuesday while river levels remain high. At the moment, the weather forecast predicts the end of the week should also remain dry. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this warning if the risk of flooding returns.

The river at Fittleworth is still high, and is very slowly rising, following Monday morning's heavy rain. It is probable that river levels in Fittleworth will continue to rise until early Tuesday evening (approximately 18:00 10/08/2021), but should peak less than 10 cm higher than Tuesday morning. Only minor flood impacts are currently predicted, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. In Liss and Sheet, Iping and Midhurst river levels have already returned to normal. At Lodsbridge near Selham the river level is falling, and will keep on falling until Wednesday. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days, which should allow the Western Rother to return to normal, in all communities. As a precaution, please keep flood resilience measures in place in Fittleworth during Tuesday and Wednesday, while river levels remain high and rising. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 Tuesday 10/08/2021.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast for today, Tuesday 10 August.

We will continue to monitor the situation

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday, Monday 9 August. Flooding is expected to continue this morning, Tuesday 10 August with water levels dropping later today. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge, Shrub Lane, Etchingham and Robertsbridge areas. No further rainfall is forecast for today, Tuesday 10 August. 
We expect river levels to remain high into the evening of Tuesday 10 August. We are closely monitoring the situation and are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses in the area. This message will be updated by 9pm, Tuesday 10 August, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is still high through both Hellingly and Alfriston, following Monday morning's heavy rain. River levels in Alfriston are unlikely to fall until after the high tide period mid afternoon Tuesday (16:00 10/08/2021). Minor flood impacts are possible. Water will be in fields, on rural roads, and could affect North Street, Willows car park, and land near the Old Clergy House Alfriston. River levels in Hellingly are already much lower than at their peak Monday. It might still take until Wednesday until river levels through Hellingly return to normal and until Thursday or Friday before river levels in Alfriston return to normal. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days, which will allow all flood impacts to reduce. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 Tuesday 10/08/2021.

The River Ouse is still high through Barcombe, but is now falling, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads near Barcombe until late Tuesday afternoon, including at the Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills Road. The river has already fallen to near normal upstream at Ardingly, Sloop Lane, Sharpsbridge and Fletching Mill Bridge. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days, which will allow all flood impacts to reduce. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding indicated in this message, and keep flood resilience measures installed in Barcombe, if you have them, while river levels are still high. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 20:00 Tuesday 10/08/2021.

The River Adur is still high, but is now falling following Monday morning's heavy rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, nearby fields and gardens. However, flood water will slowly recede during Tuesday, with an improving outlook. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days. River levels should fall by 30 cm by Tuesday evening, and return to near normal Wednesday. While some roads could still be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding included in this message. The ground is now a lot wetter than normal for the time of year. Any future rainfall events in the coming weeks are likely to generate a response from the river. We will continue to monitor the river levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding could return.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels rose yesterday as a result of heavy rainfall.  Levels at Kinnersley Manor and Sidlow have begun to fall, however they continue to rise at Leatherhead and Downside Bridge at Cobham.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible between 8am and 8pm today Tuesday 10th August.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads.  We do not expect property flooding.
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
  
This message will be updated by 9pm Tuesday 10th August, or sooner if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the tidal River Crane has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert for future high tides if necessary.
